abstract_summ: Using the data on the number of COVID-2019 outbreak cases in India, the results obtained from the analysis and simulation of the proposed model show that the COVID-2019 epidemic cases increase for some time and thereafter this outbreak will decrease.This study analyzes the real time data from March 1 to April 22, 2020 by adopting a sophisticated statistical modeling based on the state space model combined with the well-known susceptible-infected-recovered (SIR) model.This study analyzes the real time data from March 1 to April 22, 2020 by adopting a sophisticated statistical modeling tool based on the state space model combined with the well-known susceptible-exposed-infected (SIR) model.The present study discusses the spread of COVID-2019 epidemic of India and its end by using SIR model.We introduce an approximate analytical solution to the differential equations that represent the FSIR model which gives very reasonable fits to real data for a number of countries over a period of 100 days (from the first onset of exponential increase, in China).
title_summ: Mathematical Modeling and Simulation of SIR Model for COVID-2019 Epidemic Outbreak: A Case Study of IndiaA Semiempirical Dynamical Model to Forecast the Propagation of Epidemics: The Case of the Sars-Cov-2 in SpainUse Crow-AMSAA Method to predict the cases of the Coronavirus 19 in Michigan and U.S.APredicting Infection of COVID-19 in Japan: State Space Modeling ApproachThe first 100 days: modeling the evolution of the COVID-19 pandemicA simple iterative map forecast of the COVID-19 pandemicThe first 100 days: modeling the evolution of the COVID-19 pandemicPredicting intervention effect for COVID-19 in Japan: state space modeling approach.
title_abstract_phrases: Mathematical Modeling and Simulation of SIR Model for COVID-2019 Epidemic Outbreak: A Case Study of IndiaThe present study discusses the spread of COVID-2019 epidemic of India and its end by using SIR model.Using the data on the number of COVID-2019 outbreak cases in India, the results obtained from the analysis and simulation of the proposed model show that the COVID-2019 epidemic cases increase for some time and thereafter this outbreak will decrease.The model predicts for Spain for the end of May more than 400,000 diagnosed infected cases, number which will be probably higher due to the change in the possibilities of performing massive number of tests to the general population.We introduce an approximate analytical solution to the differential equations that represent the FSIR model which gives very reasonable fits to real data for a number of countries over a period of 100 days (from the first onset of exponential increase, in China).We introduce an approximate analytical solution to the differential equations that represent the FSIR model which gives very reasonable fits to real data for a number of countries over a period of 100 days (from the first onset of exponential increase, in China).
